title: Chrissy Metz Warns About The 'Slippery Slope' Of Ozempic Use
description: Chrissy Metz has opened up about her health journey, sharing her nuanced views on weight loss drugs such as Ozempic.
content:
"If you're diabetic and need to lower your A1C, these are things that are important to take care of," she explained. "But if you already have a restrictive eating disorder and take something that minimizes your appetite, it can become a very slippery slope."

"I never said I was the poster child for body positivity. I just want to do what I can do to live the longest, healthiest life," she said.

"I'm at a stage in life where I don't want that to be me," she shared. "I wonder if he'd had GLP-1s, whether he'd still be around."

The Actress Champions Health-Positive Living, And Self-Worth Beyond The Scale

"I need to strength-train, eat more protein. I want to be mobile," Metz said, explaining that she now relies on intuitive eating and regularly asks herself, "Is what I'm putting in my body harmful or helpful?"

Chrissy Metz Says She's Had 'Thin, Beautiful Women' Tell Her How Important Her Story Has Been For Them

Having been open about her past struggles with disordered eating, Metz also reminded fans that worth isn't tied to body size, noting that too many people mistakenly think that if "they're not thin enough, they're not good enough."

She explained: "I've had thin, beautiful women with their jogging strollers tell me, 'You don't know how much your story helped me,' I'm just like, 'What?!' But you realize that everyone has their struggles, their anxiety, or depression, or grief over losing someone. Skinniness doesn't equal happiness."

The Actress Talks Strength Training And Staying Healthy For The Future

"We have things in common where it's not just like, 'Why are you doing this?' she explained. "Like, I don't want to be yelled at. I want to be lovingly supported in whatever it is that I'm doing."

"I want to age the best way that I can, and I want to be strong. And that's really the impetus behind any of it," she emphasized, adding that she is "nervous" about aging, and about "osteoporosis or arthritis."

Chrissy Metz Embraces Life Between Los Angeles And Nashville For A Better Lifestyle And Career Focus

"The reason why I'm there so often is that everything is very close in proximity," she told E! News in April. "You can go to three different shows, to great restaurants, in one night. It doesn't take two hours to get anywhere. It's really great."

"There's also not work happening in Los Angeles," she explained. "There's just not much shooting here, unfortunately. And because I've been focusing on music, my family's close in Florida. Yeah, it's just where I split my time."
summary: Actress Chrissy Metz has warned about the "slippery Slope" of Ozempic use, suggesting that if you already have a restrictive eating disorder, it could become a slippery slope. She advocates for health-positive living and self-Worth beyond the scale, stating that too many people mistakenly believe that their size is a factor in their happiness. Metz also discusses her past struggles with disordered eating and her current focus on music and fitness. She shares her gratitude for her support and dedication to her music and life.
shortSummary: Chrissy Metz warns about the dangers of using Ozempic for weight loss, health, and self-esteem, emphasizing the importance of healthy, self-sufficient living and intuitive eating.

'If you’re diabetic and need to lower your A1C, these are things that are important to take care of. But if you already have a restrictive eating disorder and take something that minimizes your appetite, it can become a very slippery slope,' she told People.
Still, the star, best known for her role as Kate Pearson in This Is Us, stated that if she does end up using one it'll stay her own business.

The Nashville-based entertainer noted, 'I'm literally doing it because I am nervous about aging, about osteoporosis or arthritis, you know, and because they are now discovering so much about health overall [and] it's really about being and staying strong and flexible.'
Her workout sessions vary depending on her schedule, but when she's interested in something — be it 'gardening, painting, woodwork' — she 'loves to go ham, all in,' and 'chip away just a little bit every day.'

Chrissy Metz is taking another shot at love.
Nearly two years after the This is Us alum confirmed that she had broken up with Bradley Collins, she shared an update on her new love interest.
"He's so supportive and so kind," Chrissy said of her new partner, whom she chose not to name, in an interview with People published Aug. 13. "I'm like, this relationship makes me feel good about myself? What's the catch?"
She revealed that she and her boyfriend, who is an electrical engineer, have been dating for a year.
But the Hunting Wives actress' relationship isn't the only part of her life that's changed recently. She's also begun a new health journey, in which she's been focusing on meal prepping and strength training.
"I know skinniness doesn't equal happiness," the 44-year-old told the outlet. "I just want to be health-positive. I never said I wanted to be the face of body positivity. It's not that I condone morbid obesity or heroin chic. I condone a healthy body."
Chrissy's life update comes after she and Bradley shared in October 2023 that they had broken up after over three years together.
"We've decided to end our romantic relationship amicably," they wrote in a joint Instagram post. "While we continue to love each other very much, we believe this is the best path for us both. We still have books to write, songs to sing, and a special friendship to keep us in each other's lives forever."
Another major change in her life? Splitting her time between Los Angeles and Nashville, Tennessee, after over two decades on the West Coast.
"The reason why I'm there so often is that everything is very close in proximity," Chrissy explained to E! News in April. "You can go to three different shows, to great restaurants, in one night. It doesn't take two hours to get anywhere. It's really great."
"It's just like quality of life as well, you know?" the Florida native added. "The Southern hospitality. I grew up in the South. It's very familiar to me. There's a lot of great, great aspects of Nashville."
She has also begun turning her attention to other interests.
"There's also not work happening in Los Angeles," she explained to E!. "There's just not much shooting here, unfortunately. And because I've been focusing on music, my family's close in Florida. Yeah, it's just where I split my time."

She reflects on her past struggles with disordered eating and the misconception that worth is tied to body size, stating that skinniness does not equal happiness. Metz is committed to strength training, intuitive eating, and maintaining a positive relationship with her body, while also navigating changes in her personal life and career.
